urn:contentItem:5V2J-M0T1-F03R-N15S-00000-00Munster Says Apple Will Reclaim its Crown As the Best Tech Stock in 20192018-12-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:11ZLexisNexisMunster Says Apple Will Reclaim its Crown As the Best Tech Stock in 2019Usman Qureshi

Dec 27, 2018( iPhone in Canada: http://www.iphoneincanada.ca/ Delivered by Newstex) Veteran Apple analyst and managing partner at Loup Ventures Gene Munsterhas todaysaid in a blog post[1] that Apple's stock is well positioned to outshine its peers among the big tech companies next year, Business Insider[2] is reporting.'Apple will be the best-performing FAANG stock in 2019,' wrote Munster. Munster noted that changes in the way Apple reports its financial results will benefit it in the coming year, allowing the company to distance itself from Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Google in the group known as FAANG.

Last month, Apple said that it would stop disclosing the number of iPhones it sells each quarter, an announcement that was interpreted by many investors and analysts as a sign that the company believed its smartphone sales are declining. However, Munster thinks this will benefit the company by focusing investors' attention on its overall revenue and earnings growth instead. The changes should also highlight the growing importance of Apple's services business, he said. 'We believe the theme of Apple as a Service will slowly take root in 2019,' Munster wrote. Apple will also benefit from simply not being Facebook, Google, or Amazon, he said. All three of those companies are facing increasing regulatory scrutiny over their data-collection practices and market dominance. 'Facebook, Google, and Amazon will be facing regulatory headwinds,' Munster said.Munster also mentioned that 5G will be the biggest new iPhone feature to come in the next couple of years since the larger-screen iPhone 6 in 2014. urn:contentItem:5VMC-WHF1-JD34-V30K-00000-00Murdoch demands Google break-up2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:11ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Murdoch demands Google break-upJohn McDuling and Nick Bonyhady

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has called on Australia's competition watchdog to break up Google's local operations to limit the search giant's market dominance.

Google's parent company, Alphabet, should be forced to sell or "functionally separate" its search engine from its third-party display advertising business, the Australian publisher argues.

"Google enjoys overwhelming market power in both online search and ad tech services, and ... is abusing its dominant position to the detriment of consumers, advertisers and publishers," News Corp says in its latest submission to the competition regulator's inquiry into digital platforms. "While News Corp Australia recognises that divestment is a very serious step ... divestment is necessary in the case of Google, due to the unparalleled power that it currently exerts over news publishers and advertisers alike."

The provocative suggestion represents a dramatic escalation in News Corp's global campaign against the tech giants. Mr Murdoch and News Corp chief executive Robert Thomson have both been critical of Google and Facebook's practices, with the latter last week knocking their "smugness".

The submission has been made public just days after US senator Elizabeth Warren, a candidate for the Democrats in the 2020 presidential elections, announced her plans for big tech companies to be broken up on competition grounds.

Following a 12-month inquiry, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission last year said Google and Facebook's market power was adversely affecting traditional publishing companies.

The ACCC announced a string of measures, including establishing a new ombudsman to monitor consumer complaints and another new body to oversee the algorithms that power Google's search engine and Facebook's news feed, as well as the tech giants' conduct in the advertising market.

News Corp argues the ACCC should be given these powers, rather than new agencies.

Google has an advertising partnership with The Age. News Corp publishes competing titles such as The Australian. It is also the majority owner of pay TV company Foxtel.

News Corp's push to break up Google featured in a "remedies paper" attached to its latest submission to the regulator.

In that document News Corp also called for "licence fees" to be paid by the platforms to media companies for displaying their content, and for the platforms to be prohibited from using data from a publisher's site to sell advertising around the internet.

Google Australia was unable to immediately comment. In its second submission, released last week, it argued it does not have market power and rejected the need for more regulator oversight.

urn:contentItem:5VMC-WHF1-JD34-V38C-00000-00Murdoch media calls for Google break-up2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:11ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES AND MARKETSPg. 20Murdoch media calls for Google break-upElouise Fowler

News Corp Australia has called for the top competition regulator to break up Google's operations to curb the technology company's "abuse" of its "dominant" market power.

The Australian arm of the global Murdoch family media empire, which owns Sky television and publishes newspapers including The Australian, The Daily Telegraph and the Herald Sun, sees the global search engine and its advertising business as a direct threat to democracy and its bottom line.

"Google threatening and undermining the security of funding of news and journalism strikes at the heart of our system of democracy," News Corp said in its submission to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's inquiry on digital platforms.

The ACCC's inquiry focuses on digital search engines, social media platforms and other digital content aggregation platforms that affect competition in media and advertising markets. It found in it its draft report last year that Google and Facebook market dominance had affected traditional publishing companies.

In its submission, News Corp said it supported the ACCC's recommendations to regulate digital platforms and address the lack of transparency of algorithms, but it would like the regulator to go further by forcing Google to sell its search engine, or retain Google Search and divest the rest of its businesses to a third party.

Failing a sell-off, the publisher called for Google's business units to be "functionally" separated and regulated to prevent abuse of market power.

"Google's position as 'gatekeeper' via Google Search and its market power in the 'ad tech stack' creates real and serious threats to the ability of publishers such as News Corp Australia to generate sufficient returns in order to viably fund news and journalism," News said.

With its call to break up the tech giant, News Corp has made itself an unlikely ally on the issue with US Democratic senator Elizabeth Warren, who last week called for the break-up of big tech companies.

"Google enjoys overwhelming market power in both online search and ad tech services and is abusing its dominant position to the detriment of consumers, advertisers and publishers," News Corp said.

A central News Corp gripe targets Google's use of "snippets" - excerpts of publisher-created content including text, images and video - that appear in Google's search results.

The ACCC's preliminary report found the use of snippets did not adversely affect click-through rates, but New Corp disagreed, saying the ACCC should "increase regulation", which could include "requiring digital platforms to compensate publishers for the use of the content".

Google's advertising power, through its "ad tech supply chain", is also in News Corp's sights. The company said Google shut out competition by referencing its own "advertising services for ad servers and ad exchanges, and resulted in harm to advertisers and publishers".

The Australian outpost of the Murdoch global media empire that owns The Times of London and The Wall Street Journal wants the ACCC to band with international regulators to break up Google. "Any solution must be bold," News Corp said.

On Tuesday night, ACCC chairman Rod Sims declined to comment on the News Corp submission, saying the watchdog "would not be hosting a running commentary as submissions to the inquiry come in".

urn:contentItem:5WWB-67G1-JBJ7-N185-00000-00Murdoch media calls on ACCC to break up Google2019-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:11ZLexisNexisMurdoch media calls on ACCC to break up GoogleElouise Fowler

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp Australia wants the ACCC to break up Google to stymie its "abuse" of market power.

News Corp Australia has called for the top competition regulator to break up Google's ??????operations to curb the technology company's "abuse" of its "dominant" market power.

The Australian arm of the global Murdoch family media empire, which owns Sky television and publishes newspapers including The Australian, The Daily Telegraph and the Herald Sun, sees the global search engine and its advertising business as a direct threat to democracy and its bottom line.

"Google threatening and undermining the security of funding of news and journalism strikes at the heart of our system of democracy," News Corp said in its submission to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's inquiry on digital platforms.

The ACCC's inquiry focuses on digital search engines, social media platforms and other digital content aggregation platforms that affect competition in media and advertising markets. It found in it its draft report last year that Google and Facebook market dominance had affected traditional publishing companies.

In its submission, News Corp said it supported the ACCC's recommendations to regulate digital platforms and address the lack of transparency of algorithms, but it would like the regulator to go further by forcing Google to sell its search engine, or retain Google Search and divest the rest of its businesses to a third party.

Failing a sell-off, the news publisher called for Google's business units to be "functionally" separated and closely regulated to prevent abuse of market power.

"Google's position as 'gatekeeper' via Google Search and its market power in the 'ad tech stack' creates real and serious threats to the ability of publishers such as News Corp Australia to generate sufficient returns in order to viably fund news and journalism," it said.

With its call to break up the tech giant, News Corp has made itself an unlikely ally on the issue with United States Democratic senator Elizabeth Warren, who last week called for the break-up of big tech companies.

"Google enjoys overwhelming market power in both online search and ad tech services and is abusing its dominant position to the detriment of consumers, advertisers and publishers," News Corp said.

A central News Corp gripe targets Google's use of "snippets" - excerpts of publisher-created content including text, images and video - that appear in Google's search results.

The ACCC's preliminary report found the use of snippets did not adversely affect click-through rates, but New Corp disagreed, saying the ACCC should "increase regulation", which could include "requiring digital platforms to compensate publishers for the use of the content".

Google's advertising power, through its "ad tech supply chain", is also in News Corp's sights. The company said Google shut out competition by referencing its own "advertising services for ad servers and ad exchanges, and resulted in harm to advertisers and publishers".

The Australian outpost of the Murdoch global media empire that owns The Times of London and The Wall Street Journal wants the ACCC to band with international regulators to break up Google.

"Any solution must be bold. As we previously explained in our previous submissions, Google's prior conduct reveals a pattern of avoiding and undermining regulatory initiatives and ignoring private contractual arrangements," News Corp said.

"While we recognise that the truly global nature of digital platforms like Google mean that some of the proposed remedies in this submission may require some co-ordination among governments internationally to be truly effective, we do not believe the ACCC should shy away from taking action or making such recommendations."

The company flags this market intervention should not be applied across the media industry; rather, this measure should be "limited to Google", it says.

On Tuesday night, ACCC chairman Rod Sims declined to comment on the News Corp submission, saying the watchdog "would not be hosting a running commentary as submissions to the inquiry come in".

A central News Corp gripe targets Google's use of "snippets" - excerpts of publisher-created content including text, images and video - that appear in Google's search results.

The ACCC's preliminary report found the use of snippets did not adversely affect click-through rates, but New Corp disagreed, saying the ACCC should "increase regulation", which could include "requiring digital platforms to compensate publishers for the use of the content".

Google's advertising power, through its "ad tech supply chain", is also in News Corp's sights. The company said Google shut out competition by referencing its own "advertising services for ad servers and ad exchanges, and resulted in harm to advertisers and publishers".

The Australian outpost of the Murdoch global media empire that owns The Times of London and The Wall Street Journal wants the ACCC to band with international regulators to break up Google.

"Any solution must be bold. As we previously explained in our previous submissions, Google's prior conduct reveals a pattern of avoiding and undermining regulatory initiatives and ignoring private contractual arrangements," News Corp said.

"While we recognise that the truly global nature of digital platforms like Google mean that some of the proposed remedies in this submission may require some co-ordination among governments internationally to be truly effective, we do not believe the ACCC should shy away from taking action or making such recommendations."

The company flags this market intervention should not be applied across the media industry; rather, this measure should be "limited to Google", it says.

On Tuesday night, ACCC chairman Rod Sims declined to comment on the News Corp submission, saying the watchdog "would not be hosting a running commentary as submissions to the inquiry come in".

urn:contentItem:5PYN-D7X1-DY19-C0VD-00000-00Murdoch's Fox survives vote. Can it survive Netflix?2017-11-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:11ZLexisNexisMurdoch's Fox survives vote. Can it survive Netflix?John Kehoe

21st Century Fox survived a protest vote on its dual-class share structure, reaffirming the Murdoch family's control.

Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox survived a 43 per cent protest vote against its contentious dual-class share structure that has enabled his family to keep a tight grip on the US-listed public company.

Fox executives Rupert and his sons Lachlan and James fronted the company's annual shareholder meeting in Los Angeles on Thursday (AEDT) under intense scrutiny from investors, industry peers and media on at least two fronts.

The other big question from investors was whether the entertainment company will survive against disruptive video streamers Amazon and Netflix.

US media reports last week revealed Fox recently considered selling most of its movie and television assets to Walt Disney due to insurgent video streaming competition from Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google (FANG).

Fox co-executive chairman Lachlan Murdoch was asked by Australian shareholder John Lindsay about the possibility of getting "crushed" by big tech and if it was a "good idea" to sell to Disney.

"There is a lot of talk about the growing importance of scale in the media industry," Lachlan Murdoch said earlier in his address. "Subscale players are finding it difficult to leverage their position into new and emerging video platforms."

"Let me be very clear we are not in that category."

Lachlan did not explicitly address the Disney takeover speculation that sent Fox shares surging more than 10 per cent last week.

Australian-born Rupert, 86, spoke for two minutes to open the meeting and acknowledged the "fast changes" from consumers being able to watch videos on a range of devices over the internet.

"Content is king all over again," he said. "Video is at the heart of all digital disruption and 21st Century Fox is uniquely positioned to benefit from a wave of innovation that makes this a great time to deliver distinctive stories, sports and news."

Dual-class share structure intact

Last week it emerged that long time Murdoch ally, Saudi Arabian Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, no longer owned Fox shares, leaving the family exposed to a possible backlash against the dual-class share structure.

The system allows the Murdochs to control 39.7 per cent of the voting power at Fox, while holding about 17 per cent of the company's equity.

A New York-based activist investor, the Nathan Cummings Foundation, submitted a proposal to move to a one-vote per share system and replace the Fox A (non voting) and Fox B shares (voting) held by the Murdoch family.

The company said 412.5 million votes were cast in support of keeping the dual-class structure; 313.7 million were cast to eliminate it.

ValueAct Capital Management, an activist investor represented on the Fox board by co-founder Jeffrey Ubben, controls 5.9 per cent of Fox B shares.

The final vote tally suggests that outside of the Murdoch family and ValueAct, presuming it voted to retain the dual-class system, most other voting shareholders supported eliminating the system.

Advisory firms ISS and Glass Lewis supported the Nathan Cummings proposal.

Before Nathan Cummings addressed the 28-minute meeting to gin up support for the foundation's proposal, Lachlan Murdoch announced a preliminary count of proxy votes - more than a majority of the eligible votes cast - taken before the meeting began had defeated the proposal.

The final vote tally was provided after the US stock market closed.

Fox sees Sky approval next year

Nathan Cummings Foundation representative Roxana Tynan said the dual-class structure gave some shareholders "disproportionate power" and risked creating corporate governance failures.

She pointed to the 2011 British phone hacking scandal at Fox's predecessor company News Corp and recent sexual harassment allegations against Fox News stars.

"These scandals have once again imperilled efforts to gain control of Sky Plc," she said.

Fox is trying to acquire the remaining 61 per cent share of British satellite giant Sky that it doesn't already own. The deal is facing tough political and regulatory scrutiny in the UK due to reputation questions about the Murdochs and Fox.

Lachlan said Fox was confident the Sky deal would be approved by the middle of next year.

Fox's directors were re-elected and the company's executive pay plan supported, according to the preliminary vote count.

Fox director Viet Dinh said the dual-class capital structure enhanced the company's ability to focus on its long-term business strategy to create sustainable returns for shareholders and helped attract investors who liked Rupert Murdoch's successful leadership.

He said dual-class structures were not unusual among public media companies.

Conference celebrates ‘China’s internet’

The World Internet Conference that took place last week revealed a few nuggets about the personal habits of China’s web tycoons. During the three-day event – which was held in Wuzhen, Zhejiang province – Robin Li, CEO of search engine firm Baidu, told the audience that he is an early-riser. “I wake up early every day,” he admitted. “More often than not, I’m up at 5am and then I will start to panic. I think about all the opportunities there are in the tech industry and how there is no way I can do everything and will have to narrow my focus.”

But Li isn’t the only one with a lot on his mind. Jack Ma, too, says he has been losing sleep, although his problem is slightly different – how best to spend Alibaba’s cash.

“As our business continues to grow, all the profits we make ought to be spent on helping improve the lives of others. If you are really rich and yet you can’t spend the money well, what’s the point of having so much,” asked the chairman of Alibaba Group.

Leading names from firms worth $2.5 trillion gathered to hear the views of the Chinese internet tycoons (Premier Li Keqiang also made an appearance). But it was another attendee – Fang Binxing – who offered the timely reminder of why it might be a little paradoxical to hold a global internet conference in China.

Fang, of course, is the man credited with creating the Great Firewall – the technology that segregates China’s internet from the rest of the web, blocking unwanted foreign sites. Somewhat deliciously, this filter was deactivated at the Wuzhen event, with attendees enjoying unfettered access to forbidden sites including Facebook and YouTube.

The temporary access didn’t last beyond the conference itself, although the people of Wuzhen are now benefiting from a free Wi-Fi service that was installed for the delegates.

Wuzhen ­– a canal town with architecture dating back to the Ming Dynasty – is little known internationally. But in many ways it symbolises China’s own development in the tech world, says National Business Daily. While the country is known for its 5,000-year history, it now wants to be recognised as home to some of the world’s biggest tech firms.

Or as Tencent’s Pony Ma put it: “Out of the world’s 10 largest internet companies six are from the US but China accounts for four. Compared to the industrial revolution era, the gap between China and the rest of the world in advanced technology has narrowed significantly.”

The state-run newspaper China Press made a similar point: “The speed of China’s mobile and internet development is nothing short of extraordinary. No matter how many big tech bosses show up, or how many new contracts are signed during the conference, what’s important is that China wants the world to see where its internet sector is at today.”

The gathering in Wuzhen was also a “coming out party” for the people who regulate China’s interent, suggests The Paper, a website. Lu Wei, director of the new internet regulator (established in February), said China wants the World Internet Conference to become the industry’s answer to the World Economic Forum of Davos.

Lu also took the stage to explain his regulatory mission: to ensure that China’s internet is clean and controlled.

It was a message that required a metaphor, though not one likely to get Silicon Valley executives too excited.

“Cyberspace should be free and open, with rules to follow and always following the rule of law,” Lu proclaimed. “Just like this place (Wuzhen), crowded with tourists but perfectly ordered.”

Quite how “free and open” the Chinese internet is today wasn’t one of the topics up for debate at the event. Perhaps that explains why the only major international tech boss at the conference was Paul Jacobs, the chairman of smartphone chipmaker Qualcomm. But there was another explanation for Jacobs being in town: he was meeting Premier Li to discuss Qualcomm’s alleged antitrust violations in China, the verdict on which is imminent and it’s rumoured will involve a significant fine.

Just as another one seems to put down roots, BAM! it gets axed; usually because a) it's getting kicked out of its space or b) it's no longer financially viable.

For years, we seemed OK with these losses. We'd cry at the news of another closure - "Oh no! I saw ______ there! My past is being obliterated!" - but ultimately, we'd just end up shrugging our shoulders as the Sidetrack Cafe, Seedy's, kHz, Elevation Room, New City, and yes, even Red's/Edmonton Event Centre disappeared from our lives.

In 2015, however, our vanishing venues finally got top billing. We lost five more rooms - the Roxy, The ARTery, The Pawn Shop, Wunderbar, and SPACE. Two filmmakers unveiled their documentary, Dead Venues, about some of Edmonton's former hallowed halls. And one ambitious musician, Thom Bennett, decided to put an end to the phenomenon, or at the very least, slow it down.

He's the chief gardener behind ELM, or the Edmonton Live Music Initiative, a partnership between the City of Edmonton, Edmonton Arts Council and Alberta Music.

Bennett wants to grow a vibrant and stable music scene by making it easier for venues to operate, and therefore, nurture the city's performers. He proposes to do so with a series of financial incentives and zoning/licensing changes - perhaps even creating a live music district on par with the world-famous Sixth Street in Austin, Texas.

"Frankly, it took me a long time to realize that, in the arts industry, you need to be your own boss," he says. "You have to have the chutzpah or the fire to make something happen instead of waiting around for it to happen. I think I spent a large part of my career waiting and complaining instead of doing something about it. So I just decided to do something about it."

Bennett, 37, was also a bit of a late bloomer as a musician. He was 17 when he got his first drum kit, then enrolled in MacEwan's music program after a two-year stint in the University of Alberta's environmental sciences program.

Nowadays, he plays with one of Edmonton's most successful jazz acts, AB/Trio, and performs/records with dozens of musicians - from soul-pop vocalist Ann Vriend to Kubasonics, an Ukrainian folk band.

Bennett pitched the ELM Initiative to Coun. Scott McKeen in January, weeks before the City of Edmonton bought The ARTery's dilapidated building and forced the venue to leave due to structural issues. The city plans to tear down the building and use the site as storage during construction of the Valley Line LRT. "Thom's an astute guy with a comprehensive view of live music and the issues around it," says McKeen. "So he didn't just shill for musicians, or venues, but talked about the state of affairs and how government could be a force for good. Instantly, we started brainstorming ideas and he ran with them."

In October, ELM held its first brainstorming session with more than 40 venue owners, gig promoters, musicians, journalists, publicists, festival directors, politicians and city bureaucrats. They talked about a range of issues, from permits to marketing to audience behaviour. Do people even care about live music anymore?

Bennett also introduced two of his main ideas - extending alcohol sales and offering grants for venues. As part of a pilot project, three venues will receive grants to cover half of their musicians' fees for six months. For every $1 invested in the arts, there's a return of $12, according to some economic impact studies.

"If musicians are getting paid less, they don't have as much time to work on their craft, and then the quality goes down and people don't want to come out and then musicians get paid even less," says Bennett. "It's a downward spiral. You need to invest more money to get more quality."

As fruitful as the session was, Bennett still has to iron out some of the adversarial relationships within Edmonton's music scene. Artists don't always think venues have their best interests at heart. Some venue owners don't think it's fair for their competitors to get grants. And some owners, present and potential, think the city itself is hindering progress. The Aviary, most recently, was denied a development permit because it didn't have any parking stalls.

Bennett is now planning to work with the city to devise a business licence for live music venues, which might also end up solving some of the current zoning issues.

At the moment, there is no category exclusively for live music venues.

The Mercury Room, for example, is classified as a restaurant. Other available licences include spectator entertainment establishment, after-hours dance club, and premises offering alcohol sales.

ELM is also making headway on changing Alberta liquor regulations to benefit venues. Earlier this month, the legislature passed a motion to allow MLA David Shepherd to explore some possibilities, including extending alcohol sales by an hour to 3 a.m., or giving venues a price reduction on their booze.

Licensing, grants and zoning are definitely not part of the glamorous side of music, but Bennett knows those subjects are essential - to musicians and Edmonton as a whole.

"I didn't get into music for the money. I love what I do and I want to keep doing what I love every day. But at the same time, there's a huge economic benefit to having a healthy music scene - it attracts people here, it keeps people here, both artists and people who want to live in a vibrant community. That's why Austin has such a big tech community. It's a young population that works in tech and they want to go out and they want to do stuff. I think (Edmonton) is starting to wake up in that respect."

urn:contentItem:60T1-N7T1-DY1R-B3J0-00000-00Musk's enthusiasm seems to be on the tightrope: Chris Bryant2020-09-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:11ZLexisNexisMusk's enthusiasm seems to be on the tightrope: Chris Bryant


(Bloomberg) -- We finally have at least a partial explanation as to why Tesla Inc.'s stocks won 500% this year: massive bets on promising technology stocks by SoftBank Group Corp. and others that use stock derivatives. The extraordinary boom valued Elon Musk's electric car business at $464 billion during the peak at the end of August, when only six U.S. companies were worth more.


Unfortunately for Tesla's devoted followers and retail investors who keep an account of their profits, the increase in market value has very little to do with higher vehicle sales.
Rather, these are partly old financial speculations. If that feverish feeling suddenly cools, stocks could be vulnerable to another massive sale. Tesla's stock has fallen 16% since early September, incinerating $75 billion in paper earnings, and fell by about 15% in pre-market operations tuesday when the company was not added to the S&P; 500 index. The news that General Motors Co. has taken a $2 billion stake in Tesla's rival Nikola Corp. will not have helped.
Not everyone accepts the argument that SoftBank's huge derivatives bets drove the epic rise in technology stocks, including Tesla, as the Financial Times reported last week. But it is certainly plausible that speculative purchases of buying options, which give the investor the right to buy a stock at a specific price, by a much larger cohort of retailers and other investors, played a role in the uptick.
When brokers sell short-term buying options, they often need to cover their exposure by buying the underlying stocks. It can be evidenced how a cycle of price increases could be perpetuated.
Purchase options purchases have been buoyant lately, and the volumes in Tesla's stock negotiations have been staggering: nearly $65 billion of its shares changed hands in just one day in mid-July, according to Bloomberg data. Tesla's recent 5/1 stock split seemed specifically designed to encourage more purchases by making the nominal cost of stock cheaper. Shares gained about 80% after the announcement in early August.
The earnings of the stock were much higher than those of most major technology (see chart below), and also challenged any simple explanation. Unlike the Amazon.com Inc., for example, Tesla has not obtained a material benefit from the pandemic. By contrast, his car plant in California had to close for a while.
And while some investors perceive high-cap technology stocks like Alphabet Inc., with their massive cash flows and entrenched market positions, such as shelters, Tesla also doesn't match that description either.
If we eliminate the benefit of selling pollution regulatory credits to rival manufacturers, Tesla's auto business continues to generate losses and faces increasing competition as industry giants begin mass-producing their own electric vehicles.
To be fair, Tesla has built an attractive brand and car features and automated driving features improve the longer it has it. It has also improved its manufacture; a new Shanghai plant began operations in a very short time.
Meanwhile, tesla's $5 billion stock sale announced last week will help pay for its spending plans, including new factories in Germany and Texas, and provides a safety net in casefinancial setbacks. The company's inflated valuation means that the issuance of all these shares will hardly dilute shareholders.
While Tesla has repeatedly shown that it can raise massive sums of money, it has not yet shown that it can generate decent yields on that capital.
Its current market capitalization of US$390 billion—four times that of Volkswagen AG, the world's largest automaker—remains impossible to justify under any normal metric. Most analysts are optimistic about big tech, but une enthusiasts with Tesla. The average target price implies that stocks will fall more than 30%.
Wall Street analysts have consistently made a mistake this year, but even Musk believes Tesla's share price is "too high." His intervention on Twitter was in May, when market capitalization was less than 40% of the current one.
Ideally, Tesla would gradually integrate with its high valuation by generating much higher revenue, profits and cash flow in the coming years. However, speculative bubbles tend to deflate suddenly, particularly if there is unexpected bad news. Tesla investors craved inclusion in the S&P; 500, which was expected to trigger even more stock purchases by index tracking funds. But, strangely, Tesla isn't on the new list.
In the real world, it is becoming increasingly difficult to ignore the avalanche of rival new electric cars coming to market. That might explain why Tesla's revenue growth has been so mediocre lately.
Competition is most evident in Europe, where there is stricter regulation. Tesla's European sales and market share have declined this year, and this regardless of the departure of several Volkswagen electric SUVs at interesting prices. The VW group will likely outperform Tesla to become the world's largest electric car manufacturer in a couple of years.
Musk is a master at maintaining enthusiasm, either by announcing new product categories such as the Cybertruck van, or by alluding to new technologies such as fully automated driving. And yet the company's current automated driving capabilities have received mixed reviews.
Tesla Battery Day at the end of this month will likely offer an additional boost of investor enthusiasm. But to keep the stock price high, Musk will need to be in shape.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And thank you for watching FBN:am, now over to Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday and thanks so much. Good morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Tesla trouble, the Securities and Exchange Commission now officially investigating whether CEO Elon Musk was truthful with his tweet about taking the company private. The fallout coming up this morning, the stock is down better than one percent right now.

Futures, little change this morning take a look, Dow Industrials, S&P500, and the NASDAQ up which is by a fraction this morning. This after a mix performance yesterday on the Wall Street for stocks, the NASDAQ was the top performer up just about four points at the close. The Dow Industrials losing 45 points at the close yesterday.

In Europe this morning markets are edging lower take a look, DAX Index is higher by just about five points but the FT-100 down two-thirds of a percent, 47 points lower, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down about a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly higher, as you can see the session Nikkei Average down a quarter of a percent but look at the Chinese market, Shanghai Composite up almost two percent.

A race against time, rescuers are searching for survivors after another major earthquake overnight, we have the very latest coming out of Indonesia this morning.

Then new questions over oil production data, the Saudi is pushing back on reports of increase supply, what that means for crude prices currently sitting at $66.90 a barrel.

Let's call the whole thing off, Rite Aid and Albertsons terminating their merger deal, what is behind this move this morning coming up.

And then from the court to the sky, the Harlem Globe Trotters making a trick shot from an airplane, more at this incredible video, look at that, later this hour.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Kristina Partsinevelos with us this morning. With the Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman is here. And former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate Mike Huckabee. Great to see everybody this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be with you Maria, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Good morning. I'm so happy you're here for three hours.

HUCKABEE: Great to be back. You bet.

BARTIROMO: Governor, great to see you. And you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations on the book.

FREEMAN: Oh, thank you.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Woo-hoo.

BARTIROMO: "Borrowed Times" --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- "Two Centuries of Booms, Busts, and Bailouts at Citi."

HUCKABEE: Oh, right.

BARTIROMO: Just published a couple of days ago. Why did you choose Citi to write a book, James?

FREEMAN: Well it's the classic too big to fail bank. It was -- my co- author Vern McKinley who brought the idea to me and the lesson here is really amazing. You had a really strong healthy vibrant institution. It was so strong it even bailed out the government at times when it was a completely free institution with no taxpayer backing. Then --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

FREEMAN: -- about a hundred years ago we get the Federal Reserve, we get the safety net, taxpayer standing behind it and it's a series of crisis ever since. So it's a -- it's a real lesson about the corrosive nature of the safety net.

BARTIROMO: And it's -- and it's an important book because it's important to tell us exactly what happened in history. "Borrowed Time" is the -- is the name. Congrats to you, we're going to talk a lot about your new book - -

FREEMAN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: -- this morning James Freeman. First though our top story right now and that is Wall Street and Washington telling Tesla, "Show me the money." The Securities and Exchange Commission is now investigating where the CEO Elon Musk's tweet yesterday was truthful.

He tweeted Tuesday this, "I'm considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share. Funding secured." Joining us right now is Mainstay Capital Management CEO, Chief Investment Strategist David Kudla. David, good to see you this morning.

DAVID KUDLA, CEO, MAINSTAY CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Good morning Maria.

BARTIROMO: And I'm glad you're here because you shorted Tesla over the past two days and you've been watching this company and covering it for a long time, your reaction to what has taken place David.

KUDLA: Well, you know, if we look at what's happened over the past couple of days the stock never approached $420, the apparent deal price. It reached the high of $387 after that tweet came out two days ago, in premarket today it's more than $20.00 off that price.

So the market is losing faith in this deal. And if we look at the merits of it, I own a very small company by comparison, if I were going to sell it and arrive at a price, it would take more than a week of discussion to do that. If I were doing the largest LBO in history they said they talked about, the board talked about this last week to arrive at a price in secure funding, I think it would take a lot longer than one week. It's just hard to believe this is real.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean he said funding secured which really was a head- scratcher because you're talking about something like $75 billion, right, to get to a $420 price.

KUDLA: Right. Right.

BARTIROMO: So how do you -- so you're questioning whether or not the funding is secured.

KUDLA: Yes. I think everybody is questioning that. And now as we know, the SEC is questioning it and why all the mystery? If he knows the price or Tesla knows the price and why all the mystery on who is the buyer or who are the buyers?

BARTIROMO: Yes. It was pretty clear yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was going to be knocking on the company's door after that tweet James.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think this may be a question for a Securities lower but it may come down to -- a lot is going to hinge on this word secure. Does this mean he made a few calls and he was confident he could get the money or does he probably need a letter from a bank saying, "You have the X billion?"

KUDLA: Well James, if you look at the details that came out later on the blog and on the memo and rather than adding more detail or more certainty, it was a little bit more -- a little bit more vague.

You know, he talked about -- it almost look like more of a letter of intent or a plan to have a plan rather than adding more certainty to the original tweet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Kristina, we know that he's wanting to stick it to the shorts for some time.

PARTSINEVELOS: Right. And right now the latest numbers of the shorts consist of 20 percent of the float. Critics have complained that the broadcast is too long, too boring, too political, too condescending -- oh, maybe that's just my view.

Audiences would appear to agree, giving me telecast, its lowest ratings on record last February when a mere 26.5 million people tuned in. Remember, the Super Bowl got 107 million. Academy CEO Dawn Hudson said the board is, quote, committed to producing an entertaining show in three hours. Wow. Three -- it takes you three hours? The move was met with a frenzy of criticism, particularly from in the street journalists. Atlantic reporter David Sims called the (INAUDIBLE) award, the Black Panther memorial award for movie that were afraid won't get a big picture -- best picture nominations. Other called it lazy, ham-handed. In recent years, hit films like "Wonder Woman" have been snubbed by Oscar, although blockbusters from the past like "Gone With the Wind" were heavily recognized.

BARTIROMO: So, good changes?

WILLIS: Not the right changes necessary (INAUDIBLE) always a good idea. Can we do this in like 30 minutes or something?

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Three hours.

HUCKABEE: You can get a kidney replacement in less time and it's not as painful as watching the Oscars.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts on the changes.

PARTSINEVELOS: People like -- I remember when I was a kid, I used to love watching it because you'd never know who would win and you'd sit around together, and then the outfits, so I don't think that they're really going to shorten it that much, but they have lost viewership, for sure, because there's --

WILLIS: It's brutal. I always (INAUDIBLE) 4 million people every single night, OK? I mean, think about it.

PARTSINEVELOS: But also the performance. The performances and the actors and the comedians in between sets, those are -- that's pretty decent stuff, and sometimes there's controversy that comes out of it, so that's what I would watch for. I don't watch it, but --

WILLIS: I thought you'd see the fashion and would be happy. That's all I really need.

FREEMAN: I think beyond the suffocating politics, they just -- you have too many movies that almost no one in the television audience has seen so I understand what they're trying to do here. Maybe they ought to just recognize some of these films that a lot of Americans think were the best pictures: "American Sniper" -- I mean, most people would say that's a great movie, right?

WILLIS: Right. Well, this popcorn award, that's what they're trying to do.

BARTIROMO: The popular film.

WILLIS: Yes, popular film. But you know, that's sort of like a ghetto for popular -- you know, like, though, it should really win the major categories. You know what I mean? It should be elevated to the level of "Gone With the Wind," lots of very popular movies in previous years won those awards, not anymore.

FREEMAN: People don't watch the Oscars, though, because they want a political lecture that insults half of America. They want to -- they want to escape from all of that and have entertainment. When the celebrities go up there and lecture us and preach to us and point their fingers --

PARTSINEVELOS: They don't do that all the time during Oscars. I'm going to fight back against that. If you watch the full show --

BARTIROMO: It's become much more political.

PARTSINEVELOS: -- not all politics.

BARTIROMO: But it has become much more political.

HUCKABEE: It doesn't have to be all politics, but when all the politics they have is negative toward half the population, what happens? People say I'll watch paint dry before I'll sit here and watch this.

PARTSINEVELOS: There's always going to be something that's going to offend somebody out there, and usually, politics makes for good comedy.

HUCKABEE: But their ratings are tanking. It's not working. Maybe they should listen to us.

BARTIROMO: Gerri, good stuff.

WILLIS: I'm staying 30 minutes. I think I'm going to --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from our all-star panel right now. Governor Huckabee?

HUCKABEE: I want to say thanks to James Freeman for writing a book called "Borrowed Time," and giving really powerful insight into the financial crisis, I think it's a very, very important book, people need to read it, and I hope they will. James, I want it to be a bestseller.

FREEMAN: Thanks, Governor.

BARTIROMO: " Borrowed Time: Two Centuries of Booms, Busts, and Bailouts at Citi." Check out the book. Congratulations.

FREEMAN: I just want to say that the Governor is very handsome and very charming man.

(LAUGHTER)

FREEMAN: And a model American citizen.

BARTIROMO: Kristina?

PARTSINEVELOS: Well, I'm not going to -- I'm going to take a serious route just because we haven't been able to --

BARTIROMO: Hey, this is serious.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: This is serious stuff right here.

PARTSINEVELOS: You bring a wonderful book and you're a gorgeous man.

(CROSSTALK)

PARTSINEVELOS: Now, the timing just seems so awkward.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Tell us. This is an important story, too.

PARTSINEVELOS: This is an important story, but you guys are great. Saudi Arabia and Canada, the relations going on between both those countries, Canada foreign affairs minister tweeting about the human rights -- two human rights activists in Saudi. Saudi is saying, you can't tell us anything and what to do. So, I think that's just a big story, a big story.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll follow that. Kristina Partsinevelos, James Freeman, Mike Huckabee, great to see, everybody. Thank you so much. Great show, everybody. We'll see you again tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" is now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Hey, good morning, Maria. And good morning, everyone. August 9th, yes, mid-summer, dog days of summer, summer doldrums, not if --

END

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And thank you for watching FBN:am, now over to Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday and thanks so much. Good morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Tesla trouble, the Securities and Exchange Commission now officially investigating whether CEO Elon Musk was truthful with his tweet about taking the company private. The fallout coming up this morning, the stock is down better than one percent right now.

Futures, little change this morning take a look, Dow Industrials, S&P500, and the NASDAQ up which is by a fraction this morning. This after a mix performance yesterday on the Wall Street for stocks, the NASDAQ was the top performer up just about four points at the close. The Dow Industrials losing 45 points at the close yesterday.

In Europe this morning markets are edging lower take a look, DAX Index is higher by just about five points but the FT-100 down two-thirds of a percent, 47 points lower, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down about a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly higher, as you can see the session Nikkei Average down a quarter of a percent but look at the Chinese market, Shanghai Composite up almost two percent.

A race against time, rescuers are searching for survivors after another major earthquake overnight, we have the very latest coming out of Indonesia this morning.

Then new questions over oil production data, the Saudi is pushing back on reports of increase supply, what that means for crude prices currently sitting at $66.90 a barrel.

Let's call the whole thing off, Rite Aid and Albertsons terminating their merger deal, what is behind this move this morning coming up.

And then from the court to the sky, the Harlem Globe Trotters making a trick shot from an airplane, more at this incredible video, look at that, later this hour.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Kristina Partsinevelos with us this morning. With the Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman is here. And former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate Mike Huckabee. Great to see everybody this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be with you Maria, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Good morning. I'm so happy you're here for three hours.

HUCKABEE: Great to be back. You bet.

BARTIROMO: Governor, great to see you. And you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations on the book.

FREEMAN: Oh, thank you.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Woo-hoo.

BARTIROMO: "Borrowed Times" --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- "Two Centuries of Booms, Busts, and Bailouts at Citi."

HUCKABEE: Oh, right.

BARTIROMO: Just published a couple of days ago. Why did you choose Citi to write a book, James?

FREEMAN: Well it's the classic too big to fail bank. It was -- my co- author Vern McKinley who brought the idea to me and the lesson here is really amazing. You had a really strong healthy vibrant institution. It was so strong it even bailed out the government at times when it was a completely free institution with no taxpayer backing. Then --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

FREEMAN: -- about a hundred years ago we get the Federal Reserve, we get the safety net, taxpayer standing behind it and it's a series of crisis ever since. So it's a -- it's a real lesson about the corrosive nature of the safety net.

BARTIROMO: And it's -- and it's an important book because it's important to tell us exactly what happened in history. "Borrowed Time" is the -- is the name. Congrats to you, we're going to talk a lot about your new book - -

FREEMAN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: -- this morning James Freeman. First though our top story right now and that is Wall Street and Washington telling Tesla, "Show me the money." The Securities and Exchange Commission is now investigating where the CEO Elon Musk's tweet yesterday was truthful.

He tweeted Tuesday this, "I'm considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share. Funding secured." Joining us right now is Mainstay Capital Management CEO, Chief Investment Strategist David Kudla. David, good to see you this morning.

DAVID KUDLA, CEO, MAINSTAY CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Good morning Maria.

BARTIROMO: And I'm glad you're here because you shorted Tesla over the past two days and you've been watching this company and covering it for a long time, your reaction to what has taken place David.

KUDLA: Well, you know, if we look at what's happened over the past couple of days the stock never approached $420, the apparent deal price. It reached the high of $387 after that tweet came out two days ago, in premarket today it's more than $20.00 off that price.

So the market is losing faith in this deal. And if we look at the merits of it, I own a very small company by comparison, if I were going to sell it and arrive at a price, it would take more than a week of discussion to do that. If I were doing the largest LBO in history they said they talked about, the board talked about this last week to arrive at a price in secure funding, I think it would take a lot longer than one week. It's just hard to believe this is real.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean he said funding secured which really was a head- scratcher because you're talking about something like $75 billion, right, to get to a $420 price.

KUDLA: Right. Right.

BARTIROMO: So how do you -- so you're questioning whether or not the funding is secured.

KUDLA: Yes. I think everybody is questioning that. And now as we know, the SEC is questioning it and why all the mystery? If he knows the price or Tesla knows the price and why all the mystery on who is the buyer or who are the buyers?

BARTIROMO: Yes. It was pretty clear yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was going to be knocking on the company's door after that tweet James.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think this may be a question for a Securities lower but it may come down to -- a lot is going to hinge on this word secure. Does this mean he made a few calls and he was confident he could get the money or does he probably need a letter from a bank saying, "You have the X billion?"

KUDLA: Well James, if you look at the details that came out later on the blog and on the memo and rather than adding more detail or more certainty, it was a little bit more -- a little bit more vague.

You know, he talked about -- it almost look like more of a letter of intent or a plan to have a plan rather than adding more certainty to the original tweet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Kristina, we know that he's wanting to stick it to the shorts for some time.

PARTSINEVELOS: Right. And right now the latest numbers of the shorts consist of 20 percent of the float. But I wanted to focus on Saudi Arabia given that the Financial Times yesterday came out or two days ago came out with the fact that they increased their share of Tesla or the portfolio of Tesla.

And so isn't that a sign of confidence and that possibly other sovereign wealth funds like Norway for example given they have $1 trillion, couldn't they be one of the backers of Tesla?

KUDLA: There is -- there's a lot of money out there sloshing around whether it's sovereign wealth funds, whether it's private equity, looking for deals. But the question is, who's going to invest in this company?

You know, a lot of times they're looking for companies that are cash-rich or have at least they have positive cash flows. This is a company that has a negative cash flow, herding for money. Even if this deal were to be done needs more financing. So who's going to do this deal? They've had talk --

BARTIROMO: So you think this is just a mistake? I mean, was this just a mistake on Elon Musk's part? What the heck happened.

KUDLA: We don't know. He -- you know, he's done things on Twitter before, he had a prank on April Fool's Day, he's made jokes on Twitter. We really don't know yet. But we know -- but we don't know anything more about the deal and that's odd. It was odd how it came about --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLA: -- and it's odd that we don't know anything further.

BARTIROMO: Governor, your thoughts?

HUCKABEE: Well David, I sometimes wonder, are we taking Twitter too seriously?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: I mean, my thoughts now it's --

BARTIROMO: That would be right.

HUCKABEE: -- the president tweets something, Elon Musk tweets something and it becomes the focus of a major federal investigation. Maybe people ought to step back, lighten up and say, "Twitter is for amusement. It is not necessarily a declaration of some legal document."

BARTIROMO: Then he shouldn't have put the company up for sale on Twitter.

KUDLA: It's a -- but he said --

PARTSINEVELOS: And then what about the president who constantly --

HUCKABEE: Well I think a lot of these tweets are for amusement as well.

KUDLA: But Mike --

FREEMAN: I think we really should not the company has said that invest -- they've officially said investors can look to his Twitter feed for additional information about the (INAUDIBLE)

HUCKABEE: That's right. They said this --

FREEMAN: It's official channel.

BARTIROMO: Yes, an official channel.

KUDLA: They said it's an official channel and investors, Mike, investors traded on this.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLA: People put money on stake based on what the company has said is an official news outlet for additional information on the company.

People went long on those two days, shorts went in and covered positions, there was people that traded on this information.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KUDLA: So they took it seriously.

BARTIROMO: Which is why the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into it right now.

KUDLA: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: What are the legal implications? I mean, we're going to speak with Harvey Pitt coming up in the program, he's my special guest, former Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. But from your standpoint as an investor, what do you want to see happen now?

KUDLA: We'll --

BARTIROMO: You've been shorting it the last two days, right? But you were not short going into it.

KUDLA: We had -- we've had short positions on. We've traded the volatility in Tesla because as the stock has been hiked up and gone up, it's been a good short. The air comes out of the stock, you can cover a profit. We play the volatility in the stock.

And we think it was an opportunity to short the last couple of days because we don't think this would be able to go through. Even if there is secured funding there's a lot of ways that a deal like this can fall apart.

Then you go back to the company fundamentals which we just don't think are that good. There's a liquidity problem, there's a sustained profitability problem, and you got a lot of competition online -- or coming online in the next one, two, three, four years.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's China.

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. Competitive market and we've been raising a lot of questions. But shouldn't it be noted that they do seem to have lately been hitting their production targets, David? I mean on an operating basis, isn't there a better story on this company than there has been?

KUDLA: I guess it depends how you look at the numbers. They built 5,000 cars for one week at the end of June by pulling out all the stops and using parts that were desperately needed for service parts.

We have people waiting for service parts for weeks and months. All the measures that are taking using a tent for their third general assembly line, manufacturing process --

BARTIROMO: Hey, this is serious.

Saudi Arabia and Canada, the relations going on between both those countries, Canada foreign affairs minister tweeting about the human rights -- two human rights activists in Saudi. CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And thank you for watching FBN:am, now over to Maria.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday and thanks so much. Good morning everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Tesla trouble, the Securities and Exchange Commission now officially investigating whether CEO Elon Musk was truthful with his tweet about taking the company private. The fallout coming up this morning, the stock is down better than one percent right now.

Futures, little change this morning take a look, Dow Industrials, S&P500, and the NASDAQ up which is by a fraction this morning. This after a mix performance yesterday on the Wall Street for stocks, the NASDAQ was the top performer up just about four points at the close. The Dow Industrials losing 45 points at the close yesterday.

In Europe this morning markets are edging lower take a look, DAX Index is higher by just about five points but the FT-100 down two-thirds of a percent, 47 points lower, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down about a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight stocks mostly higher, as you can see the session Nikkei Average down a quarter of a percent but look at the Chinese market, Shanghai Composite up almost two percent.

A race against time, rescuers are searching for survivors after another major earthquake overnight, we have the very latest coming out of Indonesia this morning.

Then new questions over oil production data, the Saudi is pushing back on reports of increase supply, what that means for crude prices currently sitting at $66.90 a barrel.

Let's call the whole thing off, Rite Aid and Albertsons terminating their merger deal, what is behind this move this morning coming up.

And then from the court to the sky, the Harlem Globe Trotters making a trick shot from an airplane, more at this incredible video, look at that, later this hour.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business Network's Kristina Partsinevelos with us this morning. With the Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman is here. And former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate Mike Huckabee. Great to see everybody this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be with you Maria, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Good morning. I'm so happy you're here for three hours.

HUCKABEE: Great to be back. You bet.

BARTIROMO: Governor, great to see you. And you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations on the book.

FREEMAN: Oh, thank you.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Woo-hoo.

BARTIROMO: "Borrowed Times" --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- "Two Centuries of Booms, Busts, and Bailouts at Citi."

HUCKABEE: Oh, right.

BARTIROMO: Just published a couple of days ago. Why did you choose Citi to write a book, James?

FREEMAN: Well it's the classic too big to fail bank. It was -- my co- author Vern McKinley who brought the idea to me and the lesson here is really amazing. You had a really strong healthy vibrant institution. It was so strong it even bailed out the government at times when it was a completely free institution with no taxpayer backing. Then --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

FREEMAN: -- about a hundred years ago we get the Federal Reserve, we get the safety net, taxpayer standing behind it and it's a series of crisis ever since. So it's a -- it's a real lesson about the corrosive nature of the safety net.

BARTIROMO: And it's -- and it's an important book because it's important to tell us exactly what happened in history. "Borrowed Time" is the -- is the name. Congrats to you, we're going to talk a lot about your new book - -

FREEMAN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: -- this morning James Freeman. First though our top story right now and that is Wall Street and Washington telling Tesla, "Show me the money." The Securities and Exchange Commission is now investigating where the CEO Elon Musk's tweet yesterday was truthful.

He tweeted Tuesday this, "I'm considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share. Funding secured." Joining us right now is Mainstay Capital Management CEO, Chief Investment Strategist David Kudla. David, good to see you this morning.

DAVID KUDLA, CEO, MAINSTAY CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Good morning Maria.

BARTIROMO: And I'm glad you're here because you shorted Tesla over the past two days and you've been watching this company and covering it for a long time, your reaction to what has taken place David.

KUDLA: Well, you know, if we look at what's happened over the past couple of days the stock never approached $420, the apparent deal price. It reached the high of $387 after that tweet came out two days ago, in premarket today it's more than $20.00 off that price.

So the market is losing faith in this deal. And if we look at the merits of it, I own a very small company by comparison, if I were going to sell it and arrive at a price, it would take more than a week of discussion to do that. If I were doing the largest LBO in history they said they talked about, the board talked about this last week to arrive at a price in secure funding, I think it would take a lot longer than one week. It's just hard to believe this is real.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean he said funding secured which really was a head- scratcher because you're talking about something like $75 billion, right, to get to a $420 price.

KUDLA: Right. Right.

BARTIROMO: So how do you -- so you're questioning whether or not the funding is secured.

KUDLA: Yes. I think everybody is questioning that. And now as we know, the SEC is questioning it and why all the mystery? If he knows the price or Tesla knows the price and why all the mystery on who is the buyer or who are the buyers?

BARTIROMO: Yes. It was pretty clear yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was going to be knocking on the company's door after that tweet James.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think this may be a question for a Securities lower but it may come down to -- a lot is going to hinge on this word secure. Does this mean he made a few calls and he was confident he could get the money or does he probably need a letter from a bank saying, "You have the X billion?"

KUDLA: Well James, if you look at the details that came out later on the blog and on the memo and rather than adding more detail or more certainty, it was a little bit more -- a little bit more vague.

You know, he talked about -- it almost look like more of a letter of intent or a plan to have a plan rather than adding more certainty to the original tweet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Kristina, we know that he's wanting to stick it to the shorts for some time.

PARTSINEVELOS: Right. And right now the latest numbers of the shorts consist of 20 percent of the float. But I wanted to focus on Saudi Arabia given that the Financial Times yesterday came out or two days ago came out with the fact that they increased their share of Tesla or the portfolio of Tesla.

And so isn't that a sign of confidence and that possibly other sovereign wealth funds like Norway for example given they have $1 trillion, couldn't they be one of the backers of Tesla?

KUDLA: There is -- there's a lot of money out there sloshing around whether it's sovereign wealth funds, whether it's private equity, looking for deals. But the question is, who's going to invest in this company?

You know, a lot of times they're looking for companies that are cash-rich or have at least they have positive cash flows. This is a company that has a negative cash flow, herding for money. Even if this deal were to be done needs more financing. So who's going to do this deal? They've had talk --

BARTIROMO: So you think this is just a mistake? I mean, was this just a mistake on Elon Musk's part? What the heck happened.

KUDLA: We don't know. He -- you know, he's done things on Twitter before, he had a prank on April Fool's Day, he's made jokes on Twitter. We really don't know yet. But we know -- but we don't know anything more about the deal and that's odd. It was odd how it came about --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLA: -- and it's odd that we don't know anything further.

BARTIROMO: Governor, your thoughts?

HUCKABEE: Well David, I sometimes wonder, are we taking Twitter too seriously?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: I mean, my thoughts now it's --

BARTIROMO: That would be right.

HUCKABEE: -- the president tweets something, Elon Musk tweets something and it becomes the focus of a major federal investigation. Maybe people ought to step back, lighten up and say, "Twitter is for amusement. It is not necessarily a declaration of some legal document."

BARTIROMO: Then he shouldn't have put the company up for sale on Twitter.

KUDLA: It's a -- but he said --

PARTSINEVELOS: And then what about the president who constantly --

HUCKABEE: Well I think a lot of these tweets are for amusement as well.

KUDLA: But Mike --

FREEMAN: I think we really should not the company has said that invest -- they've officially said investors can look to his Twitter feed for additional information about the (INAUDIBLE)

HUCKABEE: That's right. They said this --

FREEMAN: It's official channel.

BARTIROMO: Yes, an official channel.

KUDLA: They said it's an official channel and investors, Mike, investors traded on this.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLA: People put money on stake based on what the company has said is an official news outlet for additional information on the company.

People went long on those two days, shorts went in and covered positions, there was people that traded on this information.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KUDLA: So they took it seriously.

BARTIROMO: Which is why the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into it right now.

KUDLA: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: What are the legal implications? I mean, we're going to speak with Harvey Pitt coming up in the program, he's my special guest, former Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. But from your standpoint as an investor, what do you want to see happen now?

KUDLA: We'll --

BARTIROMO: You've been shorting it the last two days, right? But you were not short going into it.

KUDLA: We had -- we've had short positions on. We've traded the volatility in Tesla because as the stock has been hiked up and gone up, it's been a good short. The air comes out of the stock, you can cover a profit. We play the volatility in the stock.

And we think it was an opportunity to short the last couple of days because we don't think this would be able to go through. Even if there is secured funding there's a lot of ways that a deal like this can fall apart.

Then you go back to the company fundamentals which we just don't think are that good. There's a liquidity problem, there's a sustained profitability problem, and you got a lot of competition online -- or coming online in the next one, two, three, four years.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's China.

FREEMAN: Yes. Yes. Competitive market and we've been raising a lot of questions. But shouldn't it be noted that they do seem to have lately been hitting their production targets, David? I mean on an operating basis, isn't there a better story on this company than there has been?

KUDLA: I guess it depends how you look at the numbers. They built 5,000 cars for one week at the end of June by pulling out all the stops and using parts that were desperately needed for service parts.

We have people waiting for service parts for weeks and months. All the measures that are taking using a tent for their third general assembly line, manufacturing process --

FREEMAN: Well what's wrong with tent? I mean, if that's how you build the cars who cares what the -- what the roof is?

KUDLA: If you -- for people that know automotive manufacturing that walk through those plans or look at how these cars are being built, the mistakes that are being made, you know, this is not as Elon Musk said revolutionizing manufacturing.

They're having a lot of problems with building cars, having a lot of problems in execution and now, you know, Elon Musk talked about production hell, now they're facing warranty service hell and customers are having problems with the service centers.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KUDLA: There are a lot of issues and once they work through that, they've got all this competition coming online.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And somebody said yesterday when we were talking about this that China wants to own this market, the E.V. market, electric --

KUDLA: They've made a national priority.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. Let me ask you about the price of the stock, it's at $370 right now, you've been shorting it. What do you think is the right price for this company?

KUDLA: A lot lower. In premarket we're down to about $365, $362 --

BARTIROMO: It's $365 right now. So what's the -- what's the right price?

KUDLA: Well look, Elon Musk himself has said its real car company. People want to say it's an energy company that builds cars or it's a technology (INAUDIBLE) cars. Ninety percent of the revenues come from building and selling cars.

Car companies trade -- around the world trade at multiple of six to twelve. P.E. multiple six to twelve and right now Tesla trades at a multiple of infinity. OK. Some day if they do get the profitability they won't trade at a multiple of $300 or $400.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

KUDLA: They trade a multiple a lot lower.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUDLA: So the stock price should be well below $400, well below $300.
